Comment: There are two main things to unpack here. First, the spectrum of autocratic vs. democratic isn't really a real thing. That's basically borrowing from the political compass, which is complete hokum, to put it kindly. The opposite of democracy is not authority. In fact, every system of government actually depends on authority to a certain extent, *especially* democracy. If you did some better study and read some quality political books, this will never be a real axis around which to think about political cleavages. It's purely something made up by libertarians to make them sound better.  Second, term limits aren't really being pushed by anyone who has any understanding of how political behavior actually works and wants it to be effective. Gaetz and crew are anti-government extremists, and when the other side has had folks that are also anti-government extremists then they have both considered this kind of thing, but it's almost objectively a *terrible* idea. This sub has discussed the concept many, many times, and here's the most recent thread explaining why term limits are an awful idea: https://www.reddit.com/r/Ask\_Politics/comments/10661ll/why\_do\_term\_limits\_seem\_to\_be\_both\_a\_leftright/

Comment: Term limits was originally adopted by conservatives when the Dems had a VERY stable and long term majority in Congress.   One of those long timers was sitting House Speaker Tom Foley from Eastern Washington, who lost to George Nethercutt in 1994.  Nethercutt ran on a pro-term limits platform and promised to serve only three terms.  Of course, he broke that promise and served for five terms and then quit the House to run for the Senate.  When he quit, Republican Cathy McMorris Rogers took over and she's been there since 2004 so she's going on 10 terms.  So much for term limits in that part of the world.   The idea with term limits is that the longer people are in D.C. the more they get co-opted by lobbyists and special interests.  There is certainly some truth to that.    The counter is that if you've got a bunch of inexperienced people in Congress, the lobbyists and special interests are going to have even more power.  There is also some truth to that.    The problem is that no party, once in power, wants to give up safe seats by having term limits.

Comment: Term limits would give more opportunities to the far right (and potentially, the far left, though the left of late is not nearly as interested in this issue) to gain power. This is largely because incumbents are supported by the party apparatus, so while it is possible to dethrone an incumbent by being wildly further right, the money and logistical strength held by the incumbent are usually too dominant to succeed.  But if legislators were prohibited from running after X terms, it would keep a reliable stream of incumbency-free seats for the Gaetzes of the world to go after, instead of constantly trying to take down establishment candidates from the outside.  (The strategy of primarying a sitting legislator from the more extreme side isn't limited to the Right - it's how AOC got her seat a few years back, but I don't believe that she was advocating for term limits at the time. I could be wrong.)
